resources.string: Unexpected error has occurred. Please contact support team
Could not register account. Please try again later.
We’ll back up your Facebook data.
We’ll show how you use Facebook and how they use you.
We’ll give you ways to use your data for good (Future).
Your vault will be updated each week with new Facebook data and insights.
We’ll only use your Facebook login information to automate your back up.\n\nYour login is stored on your device, never in the Cloud.

If you unlink your account, you will be completely logged out on this device and will need to enter your 12-word recovery key to regain access and relink your account to this device. \n\nTo make ensure that you will not completely lose access to your account, you will next be asked to enter your 12-word recovery key before unlinking your account. If you haven’t already written down your recovery key, please do so now.
Enable Biometric Authentication to secure your Spring data and account:
Do want to allow “Spring” to use Biometric Authentication?
Spring will use Biometric Authentication to secure your account and data.

Your recovery key allows you to fully recover your Spring account even if your device is lost or damaged. It is the only way to recover your account (Spring does not have access to your recovery key or store it anywhere for you). \n\nPlease make sure you are in a safe location then write down your recovery key on a piece of paper and keep it safe.
Write down the following words in order:
Just reminding you to check if your Facebook archive is ready. Tap to continue.

Facebook may take a few days to prepare your data archive, depending on how much data you have. \n\nWould you like us to remind you to check back here? If not, you will need to remember on your own to check if your backup is ready.
Your Facebook data archive has been successfully secured. We’ve started processing your data and will send you a notification when it’s ready.

Spring is from Bitmark, makers of the universal system for digital property rights. Our mission is to restore trust in data. We believe an internet where individuals control their own data will lead to a better future. Building this protocol to unlock the value of your data is our business.
Your account has been completely unlinked from this device.
We are making a simple lens builder and store. Like cooking recipes, people will be able to experiment, share, and sell lenses to get more utility from your data.
There was an error when loading statistic for this period
Please recheck your recovery key and tap to edit any incorrect words above.
Could not sign in your account.\nPlease try again later.
We’re waiting for Facebook to finish preparing your data archive. This may take up to a few days, depending on how much data you have.
Sorry, Facebook is still preparing your data archive. This may take another day or two, depending on how much data you have.
The Spring app on your device is out of date. Please update Spring to continue using it.
Could not play video. Please try again later.
Please check your connection and try again.
These categories are based on your activity. They are used by advertisers to personalize your information.
There was an error when loading insights
You must use the Facebook account you originally linked to Spring.
By continuing, you agree to our \nEULA and Privacy Policy.
Here are 6 simple steps you can take to increase your privacy while using Facebook:
<u>Opt out of ads based on data from partners »
Tap “Continue”, change to “Not Allowed” and tap “Save”
<u>Opt out of ads based on your activity on Facebook Company Products that you see elsewhere »
<u>Opt out of friends seeing ads you like »
Facebook constantly tracks you. It doesn’t matter if you are logged in to the Facebook site or not. Here are of the ways they collect your data:
How much you\'re worth to facebook

Average revenue per user, or ARPU is how Facebook assesses its ability to monetize users. ARPU is calculated by computing revenue by user geography based on Facebook’s estimate of the geography in which ad impressions are delivered. These numbers are made public in their quarterly earning reports.\n\nYet besides the dollar value, analyzing user value based only on ARPU underestimates the value to Facebook. Even though Facebook doesn’t make much money with their users outside US, Canada, and Western Europe, they still collect lots of data. That data creates the network effect that makes their platform become stronger and more valuable over time.
Your Facebook data archive is being processed. This might take 1–2 days. We can notify you when it’s done. Or you can check back on your own.
Your Facebook data archive is being processed. This might take 1–2 days. We will notify you when it’s done.
Allow “Spring” to send you a push notification to remind you to check if your archive is ready?
When you delete your account, you will be completely logged out on this device and all data will be permanently deleted.\n\nYou can export your data first, if you haven’t do so already.
All of your data will be permanently deleted from this device.
Could not delete your account. Please try again later.

Facebook is now preparing your data archive. This may take up to a few days, depending on how much data you have.\n\nWhen you receive a notification from Facebook that your archive is ready, come back here. We’ll handle the rest.
Your account is being deleted. It might take a while.\nPlease try to sign-in later.
Your Facebook data archive is not ready yet. This may take another day or two, depending on how much data you have.

Facebook constantly tracks you. It doesn’t matter if you are logged in to the Facebook site or not. Here are of the ways they collect your data:

“Like” and “Share” buttons

The Facebook “Like” and “Share” buttons, found on almost every website, funnel data back into the Facebook advertising algorithm. Everything people do, either on Facebook directly or on sites that have these buttons, reveal information about them to Facebook. They can even track you when you’re logged out, because their extensive surveillance network on sites that link to them.

Apps you install

Facebook gets third-party apps to give them access to your data. Facebook can also give those apps access to the data of your friends, even if those friends haven\'t downloaded the app or consented in any way. These connected apps provide information about your activities off Facebook—including information about your device, websites you visit, purchases you make, the ads you see, and how you use their services.

Facial recognition

Facial recognition is a handy feature you can use when you want to call up all the pictures you and your friends, but it also means Facebook can now recognize you in photos without you actually having to go to the trouble of tagging yourself.

Online “tests”

Facebook buys data from brokers via partnerships without any consent. Results of online tests you have taken for fun, are often run by data surveillance companies to build psychometric profiles (Ex: Cambridge Analytica). This information is then shared with Facebook.

Device location and connectivity information Even without access to your accurate location data from the smartphone, Facebook uses information from your browsing habits, including IP address, Wi-Fi network, and Bluetooth to pinpoint your whereabouts and place relevant ads inside its apps. Facebook uses city and zip level location which they collect from IP addresses and other information such as check-ins and current city from user profile.

Still want to continue using Facebook? We have six easy steps you can take to increase your privacy.
We value your feedback, if you have ideas or suggestions on how to make our app even better, please let us know.

Step 1: Request your Facebook data

Go to https://fb.com/dyi and select “Download Your Information”. Make sure to select “JSON” for the format.


Step 2: Make your backup

Facebook will let you know when your data is ready for download. Typically, this takes 1–2 days.

When notified, store your zip file in the cloud or on this device. We recommend doing this on a fast Internet connection.

To continue:
Could not upload archive using the url. Please try again later.
The file you uploaded was not a valid Facebook archive
The URL you provided was invalid
Your file is larger than 5GB. Please provide a cloud storage URL.
Income Facebook made from you since %1$s.
